metadata.case_name: Appellants v. Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports

facts.text: Respondent filed a complaint on December 31, 1962, before the First Class Magistrate, Delhi, alleging that the appellants and four others committed offences punishable under s. 120B read with s. 420, I.P.C., and s. 5 of the Imports & Exports Control Act, 1947.
The complaint sets out various matters pertaining to allegations of violations of the conditions of the import licences granted to the appellants.

Chief Commissioner, Delhi, by order dated December 12, 1962, gave consent to the initiation of proceedings under sub-s. (2) of s. 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure for prosecution under s. 120B, I.P.C.

Complainant examined as P.W. 3 stated he filed the complaint after satisfying himself about the prima facie commission of the offences; received report from Special Police Establishment at end of September 1962.
P.W. 3 had not seen documents referred to in police report between receipt of report and filing of complaint; visited Special Police Establishment Office first time in September or October 1963.
P.W. 3 asked Special Police Establishment to draft the complaint; signed it on December 29, 1962; Chief Commissioner's permission already obtained.
Objection raised by Public Prosecutor that Special Police Establishment report was opinion of police officer and not admissible; upheld by Magistrate.
Appellant filed application on September 26, 1964, before Trial Magistrate stating no cognizance should be taken as complainant had not verified facts.
Magistrate rejected the application; order confirmed in revision by Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi.
Delhi High Court confirmed orders of subordinate courts by judgment dated November 21, 1966 in Criminal Revision Application No. 273-D of 1965.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Validity of the complaint filed by the Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports under s. 5 read with s. 6 of the Imports & Exports Control Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 6 of the Act is mandatory; facts and materials constituting the offence must be placed before the complainant officer who must consider them before filing; here, officer did not verify facts personally, no SPE report produced, inference adverse to prosecution.
No distinction between sanction provisions and mere complaint filing by particular officer; same principles apply.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King; Feroz Din v. State of West Bengal

respondent_arguments.text: Section 6 only requires written complaint by authorized officer; no need for sanction-like scrutiny of facts; respondent is authorized officer.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 6 Imports & Exports Control Act, 1947; ss. 195, 197, 198 CrPC

respondent_arguments.text: Principles of sanction cases do not apply to mere complaint filing provisions.

court_reasoning.text: Principles from sanction cases (e.g., Gokulchand) do not apply to s.6 which only requires written complaint by authorized officer; no need to prove facts placed before officer like in sanction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Filing of complaint is not mechanical but s.6 limitation is only on who can file; once authorized officer files in writing, cognizance can be taken.

court_reasoning.text: Feroz Din case confined to facts involving sanction under Industrial Disputes Act; no sanction required here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plain words of s.6 satisfied by respondent's complaint.

holdings.text: Complaint filed by respondent on December 31, 1962 satisfies requirements of s.6 of the Act; valid for cognizance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Laid down principles for sanction: must be given in respect of facts constituting offence; distinguished from mere complaint filing.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madan Mohan v. State of Uttar Pradesh
Jaswant Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction not automatic formality; authority must consider facts; distinguished here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Feroz Din v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied sanction principles to complaint under Industrial Disputes Act with prior sanction; confined to those facts.
Construe statute by plain words; applied to s.6.

statutes_cited.name: Imports & Exports Control Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: s.6 requires written complaint by authorized officer for cognizance of s.5 offences; complaint complies.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Discussed in Feroz Din for sanction in complaint context; distinguished.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Sanction principles discussed in Jaswant Singh; distinguished.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that the complaint filed by the respondent complies with s.6 of the Imports & Exports Control Act, 1947, and the High Court order confirming cognizance is correct.

key_quotes.text: The sole point, which arises for consideration, in this appeal, by special leave... is about the validity of the complaint filed by the Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports... under s. 5 read with s. 6 of the Imports & Exports Control Act, 1947.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We are not inclined to accept the contentions... that the principles laid down in these decisions, which relate to the question of sanction, have any application to the filing of complaints, under s. 6 of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key distinction between sanction and complaint filing.

key_quotes.text: Going by the plain words, contained in s. 6 of the Act, we are satisfied that the complaint, in this case, filed by the respondent, can be considered to be in conformity with the provisions, contained therein.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds complaint valid based on statutory interpretation.
